The quantity of seed to be sown on an acre

This WATERING PLACE IS timely situated III

Wilmington, commanding az extensive view OF

the neiehborng States The grounds OF the
company afford pleasant and shady promenader
and are bounded by fine streams.


Tie virtues Of the Waters are those OF the put
est Chaybeatc, according to the an iysls or Pro
fessor Heating, of Philadelphia. They have been
particularly etficacious in bilious and other ic-
vers, and are celebrated as fire tonic.

tercoursc bv Steam Boat lines between that
place and New Castle, to and from Philadelphia
and Ealtimore, affords facility Of commnmca
ton no, possessed by any other Watering Place
Parties can be accommodate at a short notice

ant and salubrious Retreat.

euery case where have administered this medi
! cine, its powerful virtues have not been known


to fail: this, of itself, and have certificates tc
I substantate the fact, would give the lie 10 MIR


Swairn's bare assertion. Perfectly satisfied as


am, with the increasing orders for it, which are


reaching me from various parts of the Union,

Cattle, as well as horses, have been on
served to thrive better ln salt marshes than
IN fresh ster meadows, or upland pastures;
Andit has been conjecturtd, that the herbs
produced by the lands near the sea, are more
healthy tor herbaceous animals, than such
as grow on higher lands. But It is said, that
the saline particles with which the earth, as
we'll as its produce near the SEA, Il strongly
impregnate ,occ casons this ben .,,jal change
in the condition of cattle: as the salts purge
away the foul humours which the beasts
have contracted, either by idleness, OF by
being over heated in labour. AS cattle are
naturally fond of salt, and if lett at their lib
erty will take no more of it than what is con-
ducive to their health, it is recommended To
lay common sea- salt in the fields, for them
to lick as often as they please.

From the New England Farmer.


WORMS in The HEAD OF SHEEP.


A sort of fly which natur4lists calls Oes-
trux Owls. about this time in the year, at
tacks sheep, and deposits its eggs in the nos
trils of those ANNALS producing wsrmS,
which frequently destroy them. A friend
has assured US thot tig follow ing is an intal-
iible preventive cf any bad effects from
chat insect. Smear the nostrils Of the sheep
with tar: apply it before the fly makes its
appearance, and continue the application till
its departure. The tar should be aprlle.l
TWO or three times a week. or often enough
TO keep the nose continually backened with
shat substance. Perhaps if the tar was plac-
ed under cover. SO that the sheep could have
access to it, and mixed with little fine salt,
the sheep would make the requisite appl-
cation. The tar will prsve useful not only
as an antidote against the troublesome and
dangerous insect above referred to, but is
an excellent medy against cough, rot. and
consumption of the lungs. 1t promotes and
confirms the health the animal, and would
be useful to sheep in q high degree, il the
Oestrus Owls was nor in existence.

full articles.headline: SOW WINTER RYE.
full articles.article:
You Cannot SOW lnui ~inter rye too earl,
in September. 1t it sowed be carly, u
roots will get hrm bold Of the soil bcfor,
winter. that it viii be the less apt to ne lAu
bare ty the heaving of the groUnd by frost.
In the Memoirs OF the New Yori, Board ot
Agriculture. vol i. page 50, it is observc4,
"that rye should be sowea the last week in
August, or the ii IT week IN September, at
the rate OF SO quarts per acre, some sa, 4s
quarts. But if not sowed at that tine, il
ought to be delayed until late IN November,
SO that it may not come up till spring Mr..
A. Worthington had good crop, which he
sowed in a January snow storm. Rye that
is raised on upland makes much better
flour than that which is raise On low o:
damp land"


The quantity of seed to be sown on an acre
should vary according 20 the soil, and the
time OF sowing. and the purpose for which il
is intended. it be sowed in the latter part
OF August, or beginning Of September am
intended to stand for a seed-crop, the quar.
tity should vary from 80 to as quarts, &C
cordng to the quality of the soil. Late,
sowing requires more, and in some cases two
bushels to the acre will not be too great
quantity. Bannister's Husbandry SAYS
''when this grain is sowed for sheep feed, j

for where the blade. hanln. or stalks form

slon ot seed is requisite than when the cro

full articles.article:
The spacious and elegant house belonging 10
the COMPANY, which was completed last iaa, u
now open and handsomely furnished for the re-
ccption of visitors and boarders, under the su-
perintcndencc ofthe Subscriber


This WATERING PLACE IS timely situated III
the high and healthy country, five miles west OF
Wilmington, commanding az extensive view OF
the surrounding country, the River Delaware and
the neiehborng States The grounds OF the
company afford pleasant and shady promenader
and are bounded by fine streams.


Tie virtues Of the Waters are those OF the put
est Chaybeatc, according to the an iysls or Pro
fessor Heating, of Philadelphia. They have been
particularly etficacious in bilious and other ic-
vers, and are celebrated as fire tonic.
The vicinity to Wilmington, offers at AL tunes
access to an excellent market; and the daily IN
tercoursc bv Steam Boat lines between that
place and New Castle, to and from Philadelphia
and Ealtimore, affords facility Of commnmca
ton no, possessed by any other Watering Place
Parties can be accommodate at a short notice
with dinners, collationS, Ice creams, &c. &C.


No eXertioas shall be spared BY the Propmetoh
to CRAFTY every want ofthc visitor to this pleas
ant and salubrious Retreat.


Charges will be moderate.


CHARLES STANLEY,

full articles.headline: TO THE AFFLICTED
full articles.article:
In justice to myself, have been induced to
reply to a false nd mjustifiable attack made
upon me and others by Swain, the vender of a
certain Panacea in this city do this also, in or
der to remove from the public mind, the false
impressions which may arise out of his pompous
and incorrect statement in the public prints
Mr.. Swain wishes to establish the belief, that he


is the sole patentce of the celebrated Panacca,


upon which he has built his fortues; and not sat
isfied with asserting this, he goes on 10 condemn
all others as spurious and false limitations. Now
nothing is more entirely destitute of TRUTH. |
have been acquainted with the QjJ ORIGINAL RE-
cIpE FROM WHICH SWAIN mASuFAcTuRLs HIS MED.
ICISE, FOR UPWARDS OF TEN YEaHs. IT WAS on.
TAISEB FROM NY FATHER-IN-LAw, WHO now nE.
SIDES IN THE STATE OF New YoRg, WHO HAS US.
| ED 1T FOR THIRTY YEARS, AND PERFORMED INNU.
! MERADLE EXTRAoEn1yARY CURES WITH IT. In


euery case where have administered this medi
! cine, its powerful virtues have not been known


to fail: this, of itself, and have certificates tc
I substantate the fact, would give the lie 10 MIR


Swairn's bare assertion. Perfectly satisfied as


am, with the increasing orders for it, which are


reaching me from various parts of the Union,

full articles.headline: THE. HARVEST.
full articles.article:
Our farmers this season have been hlrst
with plentiful crops of every kind Of grain
aud grass, and all we believe have been SIC
crssful in housing and stacking it without in.
jury in the least. So bountiiul display ot
thr goodness Of Hin who ruleth over all
calls for united thanksgiving; and whilst
other nations are pinipy in mis- ry end want,
plenty sheds her stores abroad over oul
land. md abundanc Is every where the re
ward ofindustry.- Penn. Gaz.

full articles.headline:
REMARKS ON NEAT CATTLE.


In Mr. iTvrSI0X
full articles.article:
i The ead small and clean, t. lessen the
quantity of offAl. @ the neck thin and clean,
60 tighten the fore end, as well as to lessen
she collar; aud 1t MAKE il fit close and Easy
20 the animal in work ). The csrcasc large,
the chest deep, aud the Bosom bread, ~ith
she ribs standing ont full from the spine; to
give strength of frame ami constitGi o., aud
TO allow Sufficient room for the i'tcstincs
within the rios. !. lie shoulders should
b. Of light bone. and round Oh 1t the lower
point. that the collar nay be EASY, but broad
20 give strength, and well coNerc1 with
flesh, for the greater ease OF draught, as well
as TO furnish desired point in fattening cat
fle. S. The back ought 70 be Wide and lev
el throughout; the quarters long; the thighs
thin, and standing mario" at the round bone;
the uddcr large when full, but thin aud loose
wren empty; to held the greater Quantity
cf milk; VITA large dug-rens to Gil It, and
long elastic teats FOR drawing i off with
g-eater ease. The legs (bslo" the knee and
hock) strsiglt, and q a nidhie length; their
bones, in general. lisI., and clean from flesh
iness, and firm in the state OF fatness. 8.
The hide mellow, and Of middle thickness,
y though, in our authors opinion, this is a
point not yet well determined


Cattle, as well as horses, have been on
served to thrive better ln salt marshes than
IN fresh ster meadows, or upland pastures;
Andit has been conjecturtd, that the herbs
produced by the lands near the sea, are more
healthy tor herbaceous animals, than such
as grow on higher lands. But It is said, that
the saline particles with which the earth, as
we'll as its produce near the SEA, Il strongly
impregnate ,occ casons this ben .,,jal change
in the condition of cattle: as the salts purge
away the foul humours which the beasts
have contracted, either by idleness, OF by
being over heated in labour. AS cattle are
naturally fond of salt, and if lett at their lib
erty will take no more of it than what is con-
ducive to their health, it is recommended To
lay common sea- salt in the fields, for them
to lick as often as they please.

full articles.article:
Ran away from the subscriber, living in New.

Cordwainng business, named SAMUEL HAMA
WAY. Had on when he went away blue cloth
coat with velvet collar nearly new; new fur
hat, dark striped pantaloons, white cotton stock
ings, and pumps nearly new. lie was about
feet seven or eight inches high, about IL years
old, large eyes, and rolls in his walk. Whoever
will secure said boy SO that can get him asaln,
shall receive the above reward.


JOHN MATTHEW'S

full articles.headline: From the New-England Farmer.
full articles.article:
From the New England Farmer.


WORMS in The HEAD OF SHEEP.


A sort of fly which natur4lists calls Oes-
trux Owls. about this time in the year, at
tacks sheep, and deposits its eggs in the nos
trils of those ANNALS producing wsrmS,
which frequently destroy them. A friend
has assured US thot tig follow ing is an intal-
iible preventive cf any bad effects from
chat insect. Smear the nostrils Of the sheep
with tar: apply it before the fly makes its
appearance, and continue the application till
its departure. The tar should be aprlle.l
TWO or three times a week. or often enough
TO keep the nose continually backened with
shat substance. Perhaps if the tar was plac-
ed under cover. SO that the sheep could have
access to it, and mixed with little fine salt,
the sheep would make the requisite appl-
cation. The tar will prsve useful not only
as an antidote against the troublesome and
dangerous insect above referred to, but is
an excellent medy against cough, rot. and
consumption of the lungs. 1t promotes and
confirms the health the animal, and would
be useful to sheep in q high degree, il the
Oestrus Owls was nor in existence.
